verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:17
verses.text: And first of all there was in him a want of foreknowledge not befitting a god; for had not Themis related to him future events, he would not have known them of his own accord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:18
verses.text: But if he is not divine, he is not indeed a god; for the name of divinity is derived from god, as humanity is from man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:19
verses.text: Then there was a consciousness of weakness; but he who has feared, must plainly have feared one greater than himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:20
verses.text: But he who does this assuredly knows that he is not the greatest, since something greater can exist.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:21
verses.text: He also swears most solemnly by the Stygian marsh: "Which is set forth the sole object of religious dread to the gods above".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:22
verses.text: What is this object of religious dread? Or by whom is it set forth? Is there, then, some mighty power which may punish the gods who commit perjury? What is this great dread of the infernal marsh, if they are immortal? Why should they fear that which none are about to see, except those who are bound by the necessity of death? Why, then, do men raise their eyes to the heaven? Why do they swear by the gods above, when the gods above themselves have recourse to the infernal gods, and find among them an object of veneration and worship? But what is the meaning of that saying, that there are fates whom all the gods and Jupiter himself obey? If the power of the Parcae is so great, that they are of more avail than all the heavenly gods, and their ruler and lord himself, why should not they be rather said to reign, since necessity compels all the gods to obey their laws and ordinances? Now, who can entertain a doubt that he who is subservient to anything cannot be greatest? For if he were so, he would not receive fates, but would appoint them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:23
verses.text: Now I return to another subject which I had omitted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:24
verses.text: In the case of one goddess only he exercised self-restraint, though he was deeply enamoured of her; but this was not from any virtue, but through fear of a successor.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:25
verses.text: But this fear plainly denotes one who is both mortal and feeble, and of no weight: for at the very hour of his birth he might have been put to death, as his elder brother had been put to death; and if it had been possible for him to have lived, he would never have given up the supreme power to a younger brother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:26
verses.text: But Jupiter himself having been preserved by stealth, and stealthily nourished, was called Zeus, or Zen, not, as they imagine, from the fervor of heavenly fire, or because he is the giver of life, or because he breathes life into living creatures, which power belongs to God alone; for how can he impart the breath of life who has himself received it from another source? But he was so called because he was the first who lived of the male children of Saturn.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:27
verses.text: Men, therefore, might have had another god as their ruler, if Saturn had not been deceived by his wife.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:28
verses.text: But it will be said the poets feigned these things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:29
verses.text: Whoever entertains this opinion is in error.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:30
verses.text: For they spoke respecting men; but in order that they might embellish those whose memory they used to celebrate with praises, they said that they were gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:31
verses.text: Those things, therefore, which they spoke concerning them as gods were feigned, and not those which they spoke concerning them as men; and this will be manifest from an instance which we will bring forward.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:32
verses.text: When about to offer violence to Danae, he poured into her lap a great quantity of golden coins.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:33
verses.text: This was the price which he paid for her dishonour.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:34
verses.text: But the poets who spoke about him as a god, that they might not weaken the authority of his supposed majesty, feigned that he himself descended in a shower of gold, making use of the same figure with which they speak of showers of iron when they describe a multitude of darts and arrows.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:35
verses.text: He is said to have carried away Ganymede by an eagle; it is a picture of the poets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:36
verses.text: But he either carried him off by a legion, which has an eagle for its standard; or the ship on board of which he was placed had its tutelary deity in the shape of an eagle, just as it had the effigy of a bull when he seized Europa and conveyed her across the sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:37
verses.text: In the same manner, it is related that he changed Io, the daughter of Inachus, into a heifer.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:38
verses.text: And in order that she might escape the anger of Juno, just as she was, now covered with bristly hair, and in the shape of a heifer, she is said to have swam over the sea, and to have come into Egypt; and there, having recovered her former appearance, she became the goddess who is now called Isis.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:39
verses.text: By what argument, then, can it be proved that Europa did not sit on the bull, and that Io was not changed into a heifer? Because there is a fixed day in the annals on which the voyage of Isis is celebrated; from which fact we learn that she did not swim across the sea, but sailed over.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:40
verses.text: Therefore they who appear to themselves to be wise because they understand that there cannot be a living and earthly body in heaven, reject the whole story of Ganymede as false, and perceive that the occurrence took place on earth, inasmuch as the matter and the lust itself is earthly.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:41
verses.text: The poets did not therefore invent these transactions, for if they were to do so they would be most worthless; but they added a certain colour to the transactions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:42
verses.text: For it was not for the purpose of detraction that they said these things, but from a desire to embellish them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:43
verses.text: Hence men are deceived; especially because, while they think that all these things are feigned by the poets, they worship that of which they are ignorant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:44
verses.text: For they do not know what is the limit of poetic licence, how far it is allowable to proceed in fiction, since it is the business of the poet with some gracefulness to change and transfer actual occurrences into other representations by oblique transformations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:45
verses.text: But to feign the whole of that which you relate, that is to be foolish and deceitful rather than to be a poet.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:46
verses.text: But grant that they feigned those things which are believed to be fabulous, did they also feign those things which are related about the female deities and the marriages of the gods? Why, then, are they so represented, and so worshipped? unless by chance not the poets only, but painters also, and statuaries, speak falsehoods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:47
verses.text: For if this is the Jupiter who is called by you a god, if it is not he who was born from Saturn and Ops, no other image but his alone ought to have been placed in all the temples.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:48
verses.text: What meaning have the effigies of women? What the doubtful sex? in which, if this Jupiter is represented, the very stones will confess that he is a man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:49
verses.text: They say that the poets have spoken falsely, and yet they believe them: yes, truly they prove by the fact itself that the poets did not speak falsely; for they so frame the images of the gods, that, from the very diversity of sex, it appears that these things which the poets say are true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:50
verses.text: For what other conclusion does the image of Ganymede and the effigy of the eagle admit of, when they are placed before the feet of Jupiter in the temples, and are worshipped equally with himself, except that the memory of impious guilt and debauchery remains for ever? Nothing, therefore, is wholly invented by the poets: something perhaps is transferred and obscured by oblique fashioning, under which the truth was enwrapped and concealed; as that which was related about the dividing of the kingdoms by lot.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:51
verses.text: For they say that the heaven fell to the share of Jupiter, the sea to Neptune, and the infernal regions to Pluto.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:52
verses.text: Why was not the earth rather taken as the third portion, except that the transaction took place on the earth? Therefore it is true that they so divided and portioned out the government of the world, that the empire of the east fell to Jupiter, a part of the west was allotted to Pluto, who had the surname of Agesilaus; because the region of the east, from which light is given to mortals, seems to be higher, but the region of the west lower.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:53
verses.text: Thus they so veiled the truth under a fiction, that the truth itself detracted nothing from the public persuasion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:54
verses.text: It is manifest concerning the share of Neptune; for we say that his kingdom resembled that unlimited authority possessed by Mark Antony, to whom the senate had decreed the power of the maritime coast, that he might punish the pirates, and tranquillize the whole sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:55
verses.text: Thus all the maritime coasts, together with the islands, fell to the lot of Neptune.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:56
verses.text: How can this be proved? Undoubtedly ancient stories attest it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:57
verses.text: Euhemerus, an ancient author, who was of the city of Messene, collected the actions of Jupiter and of the others, who are esteemed gods, and composed a history from the titles and sacred inscriptions which were in the most ancient temples, and especially in the sanctuary of the Triphylian Jupiter, where an inscription indicated that a golden column had been placed by Jupiter himself, on which column he wrote an account of his exploits, that posterity might have a memorial of his actions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:58
verses.text: This history was translated and followed by Ennius, whose words are these: "Where Jupiter gives to Neptune the government of the sea, that he might reign in all the islands and places bordering on the sea".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:59
verses.text: The accounts of the poets, therefore, are true, but veiled with an outward covering and show.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:60
verses.text: It is possible that Mount Olympus may have supplied the poets with the hint for saying that Jupiter obtained the kingdom of heaven, because Olympus is the common name both of the mountain and of heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:61
verses.text: But the same history informs us that Jupiter dwelt on Mount Olympus, when it says: "At that time Jupiter spent the greatest part of his life on Mount Olympus; and they used to resort to him thither for the administration of justice, if any matters were disputed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:62
verses.text: Moreover, if any one had found out any new invention which might be useful for human life, he used to come thither and display it to Jupiter".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:63
verses.text: The poets transfer many things after this manner, not for the sake of speaking falsely against the objects of their worship, but that they may by variously coloured figures add beauty and grace to their poems.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:64
verses.text: But they who do not understand the manner, or the cause, or the nature of that which is represented by figure, attack the poets as false and sacrilegious.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:65
verses.text: Even the philosophers were deceived by this error; for because these things which are related about Jupiter appeared unsuited to the character of a god, they introduced two Jupiters, one natural, the other fabulous.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:66
verses.text: They saw, on the one hand, that which was true, that he, forsooth, concerning whom the poets speak, was man; but in the case of that natural Jupiter, led by the common practise of superstition, they committed an error, inasmuch as they transferred the name of a man to God, who, as we have already said, because He is one only, has no need of a name.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:67
verses.text: But it is undeniable that he is Jupiter who was born from Ops and Saturn.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:68
verses.text: It is therefore an empty persuasion on the part of those who give the name of Jupiter to the Supreme God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:69
verses.text: For some are in the habit of defending their errors by this excuse; for, when convinced of the unity of God, since they cannot deny this, they affirm that they worship Him, but that it is their pleasure that He should be called Jupiter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:70
verses.text: But what can be more absurd than this? For Jupiter is not accustomed to be worshipped without the accompanying worship of his wife and daughter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:71
verses.text: From which his real nature is evident; nor is it lawful for that name to be transferred thither, where there is neither any Minerva nor Juno.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:72
verses.text: Why should I say that the peculiar meaning of this name does not express a divine, but human power? For Cicero explains the names Jupiter and Juno as being derived from giving help; and Jupiter is so called as if he were a helping father,—a name which is ill adapted to God: for to help is the part of a man conferring some aid upon one who is a stranger, and in a case where the benefit is small.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:73
verses.text: No one implores God to help him, but to preserve him, to give him life and safety, which is a much greater and more important matter than to help.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:74
verses.text: And since we are speaking of a father, no father is said to help his sons when he begets or brings them up.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:75
verses.text: For that expression is too insignificant to denote the magnitude of the benefit derived from a father.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:76
verses.text: How much more unsuitable is it to God, who is our true Father, by whom we exist, and whose we are altogether, by whom we are formed, endued with life, and enlightened, who bestows upon us life, gives us safety, and supplies us with various kinds of food! He has no apprehension of the divine benefits who thinks that he is only aided by God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:77
verses.text: Therefore he is not only ignorant, but impious, who disparages the excellency of the supreme power under the name of Jupiter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:78
verses.text: Wherefore, if both from his actions and character we have proved that Jupiter was a man, and reigned on earth, it only remains that we should also investigate his death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:79
verses.text: Ennius, in his sacred history, having described all the actions which he performed in his life, at the close thus speaks: Then Jupiter, when he had five times made a circuit of the earth, and bestowed governments upon all his friends and relatives, and left laws to men, provided them with a settled mode of life and corn, and given them many other benefits, and having been honoured with immortal glory and remembrance, left lasting memorials to his friends, and when his age was almost spent, he changed his life in Crete, and departed to the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:80
verses.text: And the Curetes, his sons, took charge of him, and honoured him; and his tomb is in Crete, in the town of Cnossus, and Vesta is said to have founded this city; and on his tomb is an inscription in ancient Greek characters, "Zan Kronou," which is in Latin, "Jupiter the son of Saturn".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:81
verses.text: This undoubtedly is not handed down by poets, but by writers of ancient events; and these things are so true, that they are confirmed by some verses of the Sibyls, to this effect:—  "Inanimate demons, images of the dead, Whose tombs the ill-fated Crete possesses as a boast".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:82
verses.text: Cicero, in his treatise concerning the Nature of the Gods, having said that three Jupiters were enumerated by theologians, adds that the third was of Crete, the son of Saturn, and that his tomb is shown in that island.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:83
verses.text: How, therefore, can a god be alive in one place, and dead in another; in one place have a temple, and in another a tomb? Let the Romans then know that their Capitol, that is the chief head of their objects of public veneration, is nothing but an empty monument.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:84
verses.text: Let us now come to his father who reigned before him, and who perhaps had more power in himself, because he is said to be born from the meeting of such great elements.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:85
verses.text: Let us see what there was in him worthy of a god, especially that he is related to have had the golden age, because in his reign there was justice in the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:86
verses.text: I find something in him which was not in his son.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:87
verses.text: For what is so befitting the character of a god, as a just government and an age of piety? But when, on the same principle, I reflect that he is a son, I cannot consider him as the Supreme God; for I see that there is something more ancient than himself,—namely, the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:88
verses.text: But I am in search of a God beyond whom nothing has any existence, who is the source and origin of all things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:89
verses.text: He must of necessity exist who framed the heaven itself, and laid the foundations of the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:90
verses.text: But if Saturn was born from these, as it is supposed, how can he be the chief God, since he owes his origin to another? Or who presided over the universe before the birth of Saturn? But this, as I recently said, is a fiction of the poets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:91
verses.text: For it was impossible that the senseless elements, which are separated by so long an interval, should meet together and give birth to a son, or that he who was born should not at all resemble his parents, but should have a form which his parents did not possess.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:92
verses.text: Let us therefore inquire what degree of truth lies hid under this figure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:93
verses.text: Minucius Felix, in his treatise which has the title of Octavius, alleged these proofs: "That Saturn, when he had been banished by his son, and had come into Italy, was called the son of Coelus (heaven), because we are accustomed to say that those whose virtue we admire, or those who have unexpectedly arrived, have fallen from heaven; and that he was called the son of earth, because we name those who are born from unknown parents sons of earth".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:94
verses.text: These things, indeed, have some resemblance to the truth, but are not true, because it is evident that even during his reign he was so esteemed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:95
verses.text: He might have argued thus: That Saturn, being a very powerful king, in order that the memory of his parents might be preserved, gave their names to the heaven and earth, whereas these were before called by other names, for which reason we know that names were applied both to mountains and rivers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:96
verses.text: For when the poets speak of the offspring of Atlas, or of the river Inachus, they do not absolutely say that men could possibly be born from inanimate objects; but they undoubtedly indicate those who were born from those men, who either during their lives or after their death gave their names to mountains or rivers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:97
verses.text: For that was a common practise among the ancients, and especially among the Greeks.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:98
verses.text: Thus we have heard that seas received the names of those who had fallen into them, as the aegean, the Icarian, and the Hellespont.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:99
verses.text: In Latium, also, Aventinus gave his name to the mountain on which he was buried; and Tiberinus, or Tiber, gave his name to the river in which he was drowned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:100
verses.text: No wonder, then, if the names of those who had given birth to most powerful kings were attributed to the heaven and earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:101
verses.text: Therefore it appears that Saturn was not born from heaven, which is impossible, but from that man who bore the name of Uranus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:102
verses.text: And Trismegistus attests the truth of this; for when he said that very few had existed in whom there was perfect learning, he mentioned by name among these his relatives, Uranus, Saturn, and Mercury.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:103
verses.text: And because he was ignorant of these things, he gave another account of the matter; how he might have argued, I have shown.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:104
verses.text: Now I will say in what manner, at what time, and by whom this was done; for it was not Saturn who did this, but Jupiter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:105
verses.text: Ennius thus relates in his sacred history: "Then Pan leads him to the mountain, which is called the pillar of heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:106
verses.text: Having ascended thither, he surveyed the lands far and wide, and there on that mountain he builds an altar to Coelus; and Jupiter was the first who offered sacrifice on that altar.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:107
verses.text: In that place he looked up to heaven, by which name we now call it, and that which was above the world which was called the firmament, and he gave to the heaven its name from the name of his grandfather; and Jupiter in prayer first gave the name of heaven to that which was called firmament, and he burnt entire the victim which he there offered in sacrifice".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:108
verses.text: Nor is it here only that Jupiter is found to have offered sacrifice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:109
verses.text: Caesar also, in Aratus, relates that Aglaosthenes says that when he was setting out from the island of Naxos against the Titans, and was offering sacrifice on the shore, an eagle flew to Jupiter as an omen, and that the victor received it as a good token, and placed it under his own protection.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:110
verses.text: But the sacred history testifies that even beforehand an eagle had sat upon his head, and portended to him the kingdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 12:111
verses.text: To whom, then, could Jupiter have offered sacrifice, except to his grandfather Coelus, who, according to the saying of Euhemerus, died in Oceania, and was buried in the town of Aulatia?.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:2
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:3
verses.text: —that the stoics transfer the figments of the poets to a philosophical system.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:4
verses.text: Since we have brought to light the mysteries of the poets, and have found out the parents of Saturn, let us return to his virtues and actions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:5
verses.text: He was, they say, just in his rule.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:6
verses.text: First, from this very circumstance he is not now a god, inasmuch as he has ceased to be.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:7
verses.text: In the next place, he was not even just, but impious not only towards his sons, whom he devoured, but also towards his father, whom he is said to have mutilated.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:8
verses.text: And this may perhaps have happened in truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:9
verses.text: But men, having regard to the element which is called the heaven, reject the whole fable as most foolishly invented; though the Stoics, (according to their custom) endeavour to transfer it to a physical system, whose opinion Cicero has laid down in his treatise concerning the Nature of the Gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:10
verses.text: They held, he says, that the highest and ethereal nature of heaven, that is, of fire, which by itself produced all things, was without that part of the body which contained the productive organs.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:11
verses.text: Now this theory might have been suitable to Vesta, if she were called a male.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:12
verses.text: For it is on this account that they esteem Vesta to be a virgin, inasmuch as fire is an incorruptible element; and nothing can be born from it, since it consumes all things, whatever it has seized upon.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:13
verses.text: Ovid in the Fasti says: "Nor do you esteem Vesta to be anything else than a living flame; and you see no bodies produced from flame.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:14
verses.text: Therefore she is truly a virgin, for she sends forth no seed, nor receives it, and loves the attendants of virginity".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:15
verses.text: This also might have been ascribed to Vulcan, who indeed is supposed to be fire, and yet the poets did not mutilate him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:16
verses.text: It might also have been ascribed to the sun, in whom is the nature and cause of the productive powers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:17
verses.text: For without the fiery heat of the sun nothing could be born, or have increase; so that no other element has greater need of productive organs than heat, by the nourishment of which all things are conceived, produced, and supported.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:18
verses.text: Lastly, even if the case were as they would have it, why should we suppose that Coelus was mutilated, rather than that he was born without productive organs? For if he produces by himself, it is plain that he had no need of productive organs, since he gave birth to Saturn himself; but if he had them, and suffered mutilation from his son, the origin of all things and all nature would have perished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:19
verses.text: Why should I say that they deprive Saturn himself not only of divine, but also of human intelligence, when they affirm that Saturn is he who comprises the course and change of the spaces and seasons, and that he has that very name in Greek? For he is called Cronos, which is the same as Chronos, that is, a space of time.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:20
verses.text: But he is called Saturn, because he is satiated with years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:21
verses.text: These are the words of Cicero, setting forth the opinion of the Stoics: "The worthlessness of these things any one may readily understand.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 13:22
verses.text: For if Saturn is the son of Coelus, how could Time have been born from Coelus, or Coelus have been mutilated by Time, or afterwards could Time have been despoiled of his sovereignty by his son Jupiter? Or how was Jupiter born from Time? Or with what years could eternity be satiated, since it has no limit?".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:2
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:3
verses.text: —how vain and trifling are the interpretations of the stoics respecting the gods, and in them concerning the origin of jupiter, concerning saturn and Ops.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:4
verses.text: If therefore these speculations of the philosophers are trifling, what remains, except that we believe it to be a matter of fact that, being a man, he suffered mutilation from a man? Unless by chance any one esteems him as a god who feared a co-heir; whereas, if he had possessed any divine knowledge, he ought not to have mutilated his father, but himself, to prevent the birth of Jupiter, who deprived him of the possession of his kingdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:5
verses.text: And he also, when he had married his sister Rhea, whom in Latin we call Ops, is said to have been warned by an oracle not to bring up his male children, because it would come to pass that he should be driven into banishment by a son.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:6
verses.text: And being in fear of this, it is plain that he did not devour his sons, as the fables report, but put them to death; although it is written in sacred history that Saturn and Ops, and other men, were at that time accustomed to eat human flesh, but that Jupiter, who gave to men laws and civilization, was the first who by an edict prohibited the use of that food.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:7
verses.text: Now if this is true, what justice can there possibly have been in him? But let us suppose it to be a fictitious story that Saturn devoured his sons, only true after a certain fashion; must we then suppose, with the vulgar, that he has eaten his sons, who has carried them out to burial? But when Ops had brought forth Jupiter, she stole away the infant, and secretly sent him into Crete to be nourished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:8
verses.text: Again, I cannot but blame his want of foresight.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:9
verses.text: For why did he receive an oracle from another, and not from himself? Being placed in heaven, why did he not see the things which were taking place on earth? Why did the Corybantes with their cymbals escape his notice? Lastly, why did there exist any greater force which might overcome his power? Doubtless, being aged, he was easily overcome by one who was young, and despoiled of his sovereignty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:10
verses.text: He was therefore banished and went into exile; and after long wanderings came into Italy in a ship, as Ovid relates in his Fasti:—  "The cause of the ship remains to be explained.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:11
verses.text: The scythe-bearing god came to the Tuscan river in a ship, having first traversed the world".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:12
verses.text: Janus received him wandering and destitute; and the ancient coins are a proof of this, on which there is a representation of Janus with a double face, and on the other side a ship; as the same poet adds:—  "But pious posterity represented a ship on the coin, bearing testimony to the arrival of the stranger god".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:13
verses.text: Not only therefore all the poets, but the writers also of ancient histories and events, agree that he was a man, inasmuch as they handed down to memory his actions in Italy: of Greek writers, Diodorus and Thallus; of Latin writers, Nepos, Cassius, and Varro.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:14
verses.text: For since men lived in Italy after a rustic fashion,—  "He brought the race to union first, Erewhile on mountain tops dispersed, And gave them statutes to obey, And willed the land wherein he lay Should Latium's title bear".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:15
verses.text: Does any one imagine him to be a god, who was driven into banishment, who fled, who lay hid? No one is so senseless.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:16
verses.text: For he who flees, or lies hid, must fear both violence and death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:17
verses.text: Orpheus, who lived in more recent times than his, openly relates that Saturn reigned on earth and among men:—  "First Cronus ruled o'er men on earth, And then from Cronus sprung the mighty king, The widely sounding Zeus".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:18
verses.text: And also our own Maro says:  "This life the golden Saturn led on earth;"  and in another place:—  "That was the storied age of gold, So peacefully, serenely rolled The years beneath his reign".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:19
verses.text: The poet did not say in the former passage that he led this life in heaven, nor in the latter passage that he reigned over the gods above.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:20
verses.text: From which it appears that he was a king on earth; and this he declares more plainly in another place:—  "Restorer of the age of gold, In lands where Saturn ruled of old".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:21
verses.text: Ennius, indeed, in his translation of Euhemerus says that Saturn was not the first who reigned, but his father Uranus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:22
verses.text: In the beginning, he says, Coelus first had the supreme power on the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:23
verses.text: He instituted and prepared that kingdom in conjunction with his brothers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:24
verses.text: There is no great dispute, if there is doubt, on the part of the greatest authorities respecting the son and the father.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 14:25
verses.text: But it is possible that each may have happened: that Uranus first began to be pre-eminent in power among the rest, and to have the chief place, but not the kingdom; and that afterwards Saturn acquired greater resources, and took the title of king.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:2
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:3
verses.text: —what the sacred history of euhemerus and ennius teaches concerning the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:4
verses.text: Now, since the sacred history differs in some degree from those things which we have related, let us open those things which are contained in the true writings, that we may not, in accusing superstitions, appear to follow and approve of the follies of the poets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:5
verses.text: These are the words of Ennius: "Afterwards Saturn married Ops.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:6
verses.text: Titan, who was older than Saturn, demands the kingdom for himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:7
verses.text: Upon this their mother Vesta, and their sisters Ceres and Ops, advise Saturn not to give up the kingdom to his brother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:8
verses.text: Then Titan, who was inferior in person to Saturn, on that account, and because he saw that his mother and sisters were using their endeavours that Saturn might reign, yielded the kingdom to him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:9
verses.text: He therefore made an agreement with Saturn, that if any male children should be born to him, he would not bring them up.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:10
verses.text: He did so for this purpose, that the kingdom might return to his own sons.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:11
verses.text: Then, when a son was first born to Saturn, they slew him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:12
verses.text: Afterwards twins were born, Jupiter and Juno.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:13
verses.text: Upon this they present Juno to the sight of Saturn, and secretly hide Jupiter, and give him to Vesta to be brought up, concealing him from Saturn.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:14
verses.text: Ops also brings forth Neptune without the knowledge of Saturn, and secretly hides him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:15
verses.text: In the same manner Ops brings forth twins by a third birth, Pluto and Glauca.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:16
verses.text: Pluto in Latin is Dispater; others call him Orcus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:17
verses.text: Upon this they show to Saturn the daughter Glauca, and conceal and hide the son Pluto.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:18
verses.text: Then Glauca dies while yet young".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:19
verses.text: This is the lineage of Jupiter and his brothers, as these things are written, and the relationship is handed down to us after this manner from the sacred narrative.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:20
verses.text: Also shortly afterwards he introduces these things: "Then Titan, when he learned that sons were born to Saturn, and secretly brought up, secretly takes with him his sons, who are called Titans, and seizes his brother Saturn and Ops, and encloses them within a wall, and places over them a guard".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:21
verses.text: The truth of this history is taught by the Erythraean Sibyl, who speaks almost the same things, with a few discrepancies, which do not affect the subject-matter itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:22
verses.text: Therefore Jupiter is freed from the charge of the greatest wickedness, according to which he is reported to have bound his father with fetters; for this was the deed of his uncle Titan, because he, contrary to his promise and oath, had brought up male children.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:23
verses.text: The rest of the history is thus put together.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:24
verses.text: It is said that Jupiter, when grown up, having heard that his father and mother had been surrounded with a guard and imprisoned, came with a great multitude of Cretans, and conquered Titan and his sons in an engagement, and rescued his parents from imprisonment, restored the kingdom to his father, and thus returned into Crete.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 15:25
verses.text: Then, after these things, they say that an oracle was given to Saturn, bidding him to take heed lest his son should expel him from the kingdom; that he, for the sake of weakening the oracle and avoiding the danger, laid an ambush for Jupiter to kill him; that Jupiter, having learned the plot, claimed the kingdom for himself afresh, and banished Saturn; and that he, when he had been tossed over all lands, followed by armed men whom Jupiter had sent to seize or put him to death, scarcely found a place of concealment in Italy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:2
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:3
verses.text: —how they who were men obtained the name of gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:4
verses.text: Now, since it is evident from these things that they were men, it is not difficult to see in what manner they began to be called gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:5
verses.text: For if there were no kings before Saturn or Uranus, on account of the small number of men who lived a rustic life without any ruler, there is no doubt but in those times men began to exalt the king himself, and his whole family, with the highest praises and with new honours, so that they even called them gods; whether on account of their wonderful excellence, men as yet rude and simple really entertained this opinion, or, as is commonly the case, in flattery of present power, or on account of the benefits by which they were set in order and reduced to a civilized state.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:6
verses.text: Afterwards the kings themselves, since they were beloved by those whose life they had civilized, after their death left regret of themselves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:7
verses.text: Therefore men formed images of them, that they might derive some consolation from the contemplation of their likenesses; and proceeding further through love of their worth, they began to reverence the memory of the deceased, that they might appear to be grateful for their services, and might attract their successors to a desire of ruling well.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:8
verses.text: And this Cicero teaches in his treatise on the Nature of the Gods, saying "But the life of men and common intercourse led to the exalting to heaven by fame and goodwill men who were distinguished by their benefits.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:9
verses.text: On this account Hercules, on this Castor and Pollux, aesculapius and Liber" were ranked with the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:10
verses.text: And in another passage: "And in most states it may be understood, that for the sake of exciting valour, or that the men most distinguished for bravery might more readily encounter danger on account of the state, their memory was consecrated with the honour paid to the immortal gods".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:11
verses.text: It was doubtless on this account that the Romans consecrated their Caesars, and the Moors their kings.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:12
verses.text: Thus by degrees religious honours began to be paid to them; while those who had known them, first instructed their own children and grandchildren, and afterwards all their posterity, in the practice of this rite.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:13
verses.text: And yet these great kings, on account of the celebrity of their name, were honoured in all provinces.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:14
verses.text: But separate people privately honoured the founders of their nation or city with the highest veneration, whether they were men distinguished for bravery, or women admirable for chastity; as the Egyptians honoured Isis, the Moors Juba, the Macedonians Cabirus, the Carthaginians Uranus, the Latins Faunus, the Sabines Sancus, the Romans Quirinus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:15
verses.text: In the same manner truly Athens worshipped Minerva, Samos Juno, Paphos Venus, Lemnos Vulcan, Naxos Liber, and Delos Apollo.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:16
verses.text: And thus various sacred rites have been undertaken among different peoples and countries, inasmuch as men desire to show gratitude to their princes, and cannot find out other honours which they may confer upon the dead.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:17
verses.text: Moreover, the piety of their successors contributed in a great degree to the error; for, in order that they might appear to be born from a divine origin, they paid divine honours to their parents, and ordered that they should be paid by others.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:18
verses.text: Can any one doubt in what way the honours paid to the gods were instituted, when he reads in Virgil the words of aeneas giving commands to his friends:—  "Now with full cups libation pour To mighty Jove, whom all adore, Invoke Anchises' blessed soul".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:19
verses.text: And he attributes to him not only immortality, but also power over the winds:—  "Invoke the winds to speed our flight, And pray that he we hold so dear May take our offerings year by year, Soon as our promised town we raise, In temples sacred to his praise".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:20
verses.text: In truth, Liber and Pan, and Mercury and Apollo, acted in the same way respecting Jupiter, and afterwards their successors did the same respecting them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:21
verses.text: The poets also added their influence, and by means of poems composed to give pleasure, raised them to the heaven; as is the case with those who flatter kings, even though wicked, with false panegyrics.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:22
verses.text: And this evil originated with the Greeks, whose levity being furnished with the ability and copiousness of speech, excited in an incredible degree mists of falsehoods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:23
verses.text: And thus from admiration of them they first undertook their sacred rites, and handed them down to all nations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:24
verses.text: On account of this vanity the Sibyl thus rebukes them:—  "Why trustest thou, O Greece, to princely men? Why to the dead dost offer empty gifts? Thou offerest to idols; this error who suggested, That thou shouldst leave the presence of the mighty God, And make these offerings?"  Marcus Tullius, who was not only an accomplished orator, but also a philosopher, since he alone was an imitator of Plato, in that treatise in which he consoled himself concerning the death of his daughter, did not hesitate to say that those gods who were publicly worshipped were men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:25
verses.text: And this testimony of his ought to be esteemed the more weighty, because he held the priesthood of the augurs, and testifies that he worships and venerates the same gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:26
verses.text: And thus within the compass of a few verses he has presented us with two facts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:27
verses.text: For while he declared his intention of consecrating the image of his daughter in the same manner in which they were consecrated by the ancients, he both taught that they were dead, and showed the origin of a vain superstition.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:28
verses.text: "Since, in truth," he says, "we see many men and women among the number of the gods, and venerate their shrines, held in the greatest honour in cities and in the country, let us assent to the wisdom of those to whose talents and inventions we owe it that life is altogether adorned with laws and institutions, and established on a firm basis.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:29
verses.text: And if any living being was worthy of being consecrated, assuredly it was this.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:30
verses.text: If the offspring of Cadmus, or Amphitryon, or Tyndarus, was worthy of being extolled by fame to the heaven, the same honour ought undoubtedly to be appropriated to her.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:31
verses.text: And this indeed I will do; and with the approbation of the gods, I will place you the best and most learned of all women in their assembly, and will consecrate you to the estimation of all men".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:32
verses.text: Some one may perhaps say that Cicero raved through excessive grief.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:33
verses.text: But, in truth, the whole of that speech, which was perfect both in learning and in its examples, and in the very style of expression, gave no indications of a distempered mind, but of constancy and judgment; and this very sentence exhibits no sign of grief.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:34
verses.text: For I do not think that he could have written with such variety, and copiousness, and ornament, had not his grief been mitigated by reason itself, and the consolation of his friends and length of time.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:35
verses.text: Why should I mention what he says in his books concerning the Republic, and also concerning glory? For in his treatise on the Laws, in which work, following the example of Plato, he wished to set forth those laws which he thought that a just and wise state would employ, he thus decreed concerning religion: "Let them reverence the gods, both those who have always been regarded as gods of heaven, and those whose services to men have placed them in heaven: Hercules, Liber, aesculapius, Castor, Pollux, and Quirinus".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:36
verses.text: Also in his Tusculan Disputations, when he said that heaven was almost entirely filled with the human race, he said: "If, indeed, I should attempt to investigate ancient accounts, and to extract from them those things which the writers of Greece have handed down, even those who are held in the highest rank as gods will be found to have gone from us into heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:37
verses.text: Inquire whose sepulchres are pointed out in Greece: remember, since you are initiated, what things are handed down in the mysteries; and then at length you will understand how widely this persuasion is spread".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:38
verses.text: He appealed, as it is plain, to the conscience of Atticus, that it might be understood from the very mysteries that all those who are worshipped were men; and when he acknowledged this without hesitation in the case of Hercules, Liber, aesculapius, Castor and Pollux, he was afraid openly to make the same admission respecting Apollo and Jupiter their fathers, and likewise respecting Neptune, Vulcan, Mars, and Mercury, whom he termed the greater gods; and therefore he says that this opinion is widely spread, that we may understand the same concerning Jupiter and the other more ancient gods: for if the ancients consecrated their memory in the same manner in which he says that he will consecrate the image and the name of his daughter, those who mourn may be pardoned, but those who believe it cannot be pardoned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:39
verses.text: For who is so infatuated as to believe that heaven is opened to the dead at the consent and pleasure of a senseless multitude? Or that any one is able to give to another that which he himself does not possess? Among the Romans, Julius was made a god, because it pleased a guilty man, Antony; Quirinus was made a god, because it seemed good to the shepherds, though one of them was the murderer of his twin brother, the other the destroyer of his country.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:40
verses.text: But if Antony had not been consul, in return for his services towards the state Caius Caesar would have been without the honour even of a dead man, and that, too, by the advice of his father-in-law Piso, and of his relative Lucius Caesar, who opposed the celebration of the funeral, and by the advice of Dolabella the consul, who overthrew the column in the forum, that is, his monuments, and purified the forum.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:41
verses.text: For Ennius declares that Romulus was regretted by his people, since he represents the people as thus speaking, through grief for their lost king: "O Romulus, Romulus, say what a guardian of your country the gods produced you? You brought us forth within the regions of light.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:42
verses.text: O father, O sire, O race, descended from the gods".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:43
verses.text: On account of this regret they more readily believed Julius Proculus uttering falsehoods, who was suborned by the fathers to announce to the populace that he had seen the king in a form more majestic than that of a man; and that he had given command to the people that a temple should be built to his honour, that he was a god, and was called by the name of Quirinus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 16:44
verses.text: By which deed he at once persuaded the people that Romulus had gone to the gods, and freed the senate from the suspicion of having slain the king.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:2
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:3
verses.text: — by what argument it is proved that those who are distinguished by a difference of sex cannot be gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:4
verses.text: I might be content with those things which I have related, but there still remain many things which are necessary for the work which I have undertaken.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:5
verses.text: For although, by destroying the principal part of superstitions, I have taken away the whole, yet it pleases me to follow up the remaining parts, and more fully to refute so inveterate a persuasion, that men may at length be ashamed and repent of their errors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:6
verses.text: This is a great undertaking, and worthy of a man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:7
verses.text: "I proceed to release the minds of men from the ties of superstitions," as Lucretius says; and he indeed was unable to effect this, because he brought forward nothing true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:8
verses.text: This is our duty, who both assert the existence of the true God and refute false deities.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:9
verses.text: They, therefore, who entertain the opinion that the poets have invented fables about the gods, and yet believe in the existence of female deities, and worship them, are unconsciously brought back to that which they had denied—that they have sexual intercourse, and bring forth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:10
verses.text: For it is impossible that the two sexes can have been instituted except for the sake of generation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:11
verses.text: But a difference of sex being admitted, they do not perceive that conception follows as a consequence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:12
verses.text: And this cannot be the case with a God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:13
verses.text: But let the matter be as they imagine; for they say that there are sons of Jupiter and of the other gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:14
verses.text: Therefore new gods are born, and that indeed daily, for gods are not surpassed in fruitfulness by men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:15
verses.text: It follows that all things are full of gods without number, since forsooth none of them dies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:16
verses.text: For since the multitude of men is incredible, and their number not to be estimated—though, as they are born, they must of necessity die—what must we suppose to be the case with the gods who have been born through so many ages, and have remained immortal? How is it, then, that so few are worshipped? Unless we think by any means that there are two sexes of the gods, not for the sake of generation, but for mere gratification, and that the gods practise those things which men are ashamed to do, and to submit to.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:17
verses.text: But when any are said to be born from any, it follows that they always continue to be born, if they are born at any time; or if they ceased at any time to be born, it is befitting that we should know why or at what time they so ceased.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:18
verses.text: Seneca, in his books of moral philosophy, not without some pleasantry, asks, "What is the reason why Jupiter, who is represented by the poets as most addicted to lust, ceased to beget children? Was it that he was become a sexagenarian, and was restrained by the Papian law? Or did he obtain the privileges conferred by having three children? Or did the sentiment at length occur to him, 'What you have done to another, you may expect from another;' and does he fear lest any one should act towards him as he himself did to Saturn?" But let those who maintain that they are gods, see in what manner they can answer this argument which I shall bring forward.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:19
verses.text: If there are two sexes of the gods, conjugal intercourse follows; and if this takes place, they must have houses, for they are not without virtue and a sense of shame, so as to do this openly and promiscuously, as we see that the brute animals do.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:20
verses.text: If they have houses, it follows that they also have cities; and for this we have the authority of Ovid, who says, "The multitude of gods occupy separate places; in this front the powerful and illustrious inhabitants of heaven have placed their dwellings".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:21
verses.text: If they have cities, they will also have fields.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:22
verses.text: Now who cannot see the consequence,—namely, that they plough and cultivate their lands? And this is done for the sake of food.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:23
verses.text: Therefore they are mortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:24
verses.text: And this argument is of the same weight when reversed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:25
verses.text: For if they have no lands, they have no cities; and if they have no cities, they are also without houses.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:26
verses.text: And if they have no houses, they have no conjugal intercourse; and if they are without this, they have no female sex.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:27
verses.text: But we see that there are females among the gods also.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:28
verses.text: Therefore there are not gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:29
verses.text: If any one is able, let him do away with this argument.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:30
verses.text: For one thing so follows the other, that it is impossible not to admit these last things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:31
verses.text: But no one will refute even the former argument.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:32
verses.text: Of the two sexes the one is stronger, the other weaker.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:33
verses.text: For the males are more robust, the females more feeble.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:34
verses.text: But a god is not liable to feebleness; therefore there is no female sex.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 17:35
verses.text: To this is added that last conclusion of the former argument, that there are no gods, since there are females also among the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:2
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:3
verses.text: —concerning the same opinion of the stoics, and concerning the hardships and disgraceful conduct of the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:4
verses.text: On these accounts the Stoics form a different conception of the gods; and because they do not perceive what the truth is, they attempt to join them with the system of natural things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:5
verses.text: And Cicero, following them, brought forward this opinion respecting the gods and their religions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:6
verses.text: Do you see then, he says, how an argument has been drawn from physical subjects which have been well and usefully found out, to the existence of false and fictitious gods? And this circumstance gave rise to false opinions and turbulent errors, and almost old-womanly superstitions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:7
verses.text: For both the forms of the gods, and their ages, and clothing and ornaments, are known to us; and moreover their races, and marriages, and all their relationships, and all things reduced to the similitude of human infirmity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:8
verses.text: What can be said more plain, more true? The chief of the Roman philosophy, and invested with the most honourable priesthood, refutes the false and fictitious gods, and testifies that their worship consists of almost old-womanly superstitions: he complains that men are entangled in false opinions and turbulent errors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:9
verses.text: For the whole of his third book respecting the Nature of the Gods altogether overthrows and destroys all religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:10
verses.text: What more, therefore, is expected from us? Can we surpass Cicero in eloquence? By no means; but confidence was wanting to him, being ignorant of the truth, as he himself simply acknowledges in the same work.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:11
verses.text: For he says that he can more easily say what is not, than what is; that is, that he is aware that the received system is false, but is ignorant of the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:12
verses.text: It is plain, therefore, that those who are supposed to be gods were but men, and that their memory was consecrated after their death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:13
verses.text: And on this account also different ages and established representations of form are assigned to each, because their images were fashioned in that dress and of that age at which death arrested each.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:14
verses.text: Let us consider, if you please, the hardships of the unfortunate gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:15
verses.text: Isis lost her son; Ceres her daughter; Latona, expelled and driven about over the earth, with difficulty found a small island where she might bring forth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:16
verses.text: The mother of the gods both loved a beautiful youth, and also mutilated him when found in company with a harlot; and on this account her sacred rites are now celebrated by the Galli as priests.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:17
verses.text: Juno violently persecuted harlots, because she was not able to conceive by her brother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:18
verses.text: Varro writes, that the island Samos was before called Parthenia, because Juno there grew up, and there also was married to Jupiter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:19
verses.text: Accordingly there is a most noble and ancient temple of hers at Samos, and an image fashioned in the dress of a bride; and her annual sacred rites are celebrated after the manner of a marriage.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:20
verses.text: If, therefore, she grew up, if she was at first a virgin and afterwards a woman, he who does not understand that she was a human being confesses himself a brute.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:21
verses.text: Why should I speak of the lewdness of Venus, who ministered to the lusts of all, not only gods, but also men? For from her infamous debauchery with Mars she brought forth Harmonia; from Mercury she brought forth Hermaphroditus, who was born of both sexes; from Jupiter Cupid; from Anchises aeneas; from Butes Eryx; from Adonis she could bring forth no offspring, because he was struck by a boar, and slain, while yet a boy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:22
verses.text: And she first instituted the art of courtesanship, as is contained in the sacred history; and taught women in Cyprus to seek gain by prostitution, which she commanded for this purpose, that she alone might not appear unchaste and a courter of men beyond other females.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:23
verses.text: Has she, too, any claim to religious worship, on whose part more adulteries are recorded than births? But not even were those virgins who are celebrated able to preserve their chastity inviolate.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:24
verses.text: For from what source can we suppose that Erichthonius was born? Was it from the earth, as the poets would have it appear? But the circumstance itself cries out.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:25
verses.text: For when Vulcan had made arms for the gods, and Jupiter had given him the option of asking for whatever reward he might wish, and had sworn, according to his custom, by the infernal lake, that he would refuse him nothing which he might ask, then the lame artificer demanded Minerva in marriage.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:26
verses.text: Upon this the excellent and mighty Jupiter, being bound by so great an oath, was not able to refuse; he, however, advised Minerva to oppose and defend her chastity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:27
verses.text: Then in that struggle they say that Vulcan shed his seed upon the earth, from which source Erichthonius was born: and that this name was given to him from ἔριδος and χθονός, that is, from the contest and the ground.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:28
verses.text: Why, then, did she, a virgin, entrust that boy shut up with a dragon and sealed to three virgins born from Cecrops? An evident case of incest, as I think, which can by no means be glossed over.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:29
verses.text: Another, when she had almost lost her lover, who was torn to pieces by his madened horses, called in the most excellent physician aesculapius for the treatment of the youth; and when he was healed,  "Trivia kind her favourite hides, And to Egeria's care confides, To live in woods obscure and lone, And lose in Virbius' name his own".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 18:30
verses.text: What is the meaning of this so diligent and anxious care? Why this secret abode? Why this banishment, either to so great a distance, or to a woman, or into solitude? Why, in the next place, the change of name? Lastly, why such a determined hatred of horses? What do all these things imply, but the consciousness of dishonour, and a love by no means consistent with a virgin? There was evidently a reason why she undertook so great a labour for a youth so faithful, who had refused compliance with the love of his stepmother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:2
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:3
verses.text: —on the consecration of gods, on account of the benefits which they conferred upon men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:4
verses.text: In this place also they are to be refuted, who not only admit that gods have been made from men, but even boast of it as a subject of praise, either on account of their valour, as Hercules, or of their gifts, as Ceres and Liber, or of the arts which they discovered, as aesculapius or Minerva.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:5
verses.text: But how foolish these things are, and how unworthy of being the causes why men should contaminate themselves with inexpiable guilt, and become enemies to God, in contempt of whom they undertake offerings to the dead, I will show from particular instances.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:6
verses.text: They say that it is virtue which exalts man to heaven,—not, however, that concerning which philosophers discuss, which consists in goods of the soul, but this connected with the body, which is called fortitude; and since this was pre-eminent in Hercules, it is believed to have deserved immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:7
verses.text: Who is so foolishly senseless as to judge strength of body to be a divine or even a human good, when it has been assigned in greater measure to cattle, and it is often impaired by one disease, or is lessened by old age itself, and altogether fails? And so Hercules, when he perceived that his muscles were disfigured by ulcers, neither wished to be healed nor to grow old, that he might not at any time appear to have less strength or comeliness than he once had.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:8
verses.text: They supposed that he ascended into heaven from the funeral pile on which he had burnt himself alive; and those very qualities which they most foolishly admired, they expressed by statues and images, and consecrated, so that they might for ever remain as memorials of the folly of those who had believed that gods owed their origin to the slaughter of beasts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:9
verses.text: But this, perchance, may be the fault of the Greeks, who always esteemed most trifling things as of the greatest consequence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:10
verses.text: What is the case of our own countrymen? Are they more wise? For they despise valour in an athlete, because it produces no injury; but in the case of a king, because it occasions widely-spread disasters, they so admire it as to imagine that brave and warlike generals are admitted to the assembly of the gods, and that there is no other way to immortality than to lead armies, to lay waste the territory of others, to destroy cities, to overthrow towns, to put to death or enslave free peoples.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:11
verses.text: Truly the greater number of men they have cast down, plundered, and slain, so much the more noble and distinguished do they think themselves; and ensnared by the show of empty glory, they give to their crimes the name of virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:12
verses.text: I would rather that they should make to themselves gods from the slaughter of wild beasts, than approve of an immortality so stained with blood.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:13
verses.text: If any one has slain a single man, he is regarded as contaminated and wicked, nor do they think it lawful for him to be admitted to this earthly abode of the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:14
verses.text: But he who has slaughtered countless thousands of men, has inundated plains with blood, and infected rivers, is not only admitted into the temple, but even into heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:15
verses.text: In Ennius Africanus thus speaks: "If it is permitted any one to ascend to the regions of the gods above, the greatest gate of heaven is open to me alone".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:16
verses.text: Because, in truth, he extinguished and destroyed a great part of the human race.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:17
verses.text: Oh how great the darkness in which you were involved, O Africanus, or rather O poet, in that you imagined the ascent to heaven to be open to men through slaughters and bloodshed! And Cicero also assented to this delusion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:18
verses.text: It is so in truth, he said, O Africanus, for the same gate was open to Hercules; as though he himself had been doorkeeper in heaven at the time when this took place.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:19
verses.text: I indeed cannot determine whether I should think it a subject of grief or of ridicule, when I see grave and learned, and, as they appear to themselves, wise men, involved in such miserable waves of errors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:20
verses.text: If this is the virtue which renders us immortal, I for my part should prefer to die, rather than to be the cause of destruction to as many as possible.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:21
verses.text: If immortality can be obtained in no other way than by bloodshed, what will be the result if all shall agree to live in harmony? And this may undoubtedly be realized, if men would cast aside their pernicious and impious madness, and live in innocence and justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:22
verses.text: Shall no one, then, be worthy of heaven? Shall virtue perish, because it will not be permitted men to rage against their fellow-men? But they who reckon the overthrow of cities and people as the greatest glory will not endure public tranquillity: they will plunder and rage; and by the infliction of outrageous injuries will disturb the compact of human society, that they may have an enemy whom they may destroy with greater wickedness than that with which they attacked.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:23
verses.text: Now let us proceed to the remaining subjects.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:24
verses.text: The conferring of benefits gave the name of gods to Ceres and Liber.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:25
verses.text: I am able to prove from the sacred writings that wine and corn were used by men before the offspring of Coelus and Saturnus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:26
verses.text: But let us suppose that they were introduced by these.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:27
verses.text: Can it appear to be a greater thing to have collected corn, and having bruised it, to have taught men to make bread; or to have pressed grapes gathered from the vine, and to have made wine, than to have produced and brought forth from the earth corn itself, or the vine? God, indeed, may have left these things to be drawn out by the ingenuity of man; yet all things must belong to Him, who gave to man both wisdom to discover, and those very things which might be discovered.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:28
verses.text: The arts also are said to have gained immortality for their inventors, as medicine for aesculapius, the craft of the smith for Vulcan.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:29
verses.text: Therefore let us worship those also who taught the art of the fuller and of the shoemaker.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:30
verses.text: But why is not honour paid to the discoverer of the potter's art? Is it that those rich men despise Samian vessels? There are also other arts, the inventors of which greatly profited the life of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:31
verses.text: Why have not temples been assigned to them also? But doubtless it is Minerva who discovered all, and therefore workmen offer prayers to her.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:32
verses.text: Such, then, was the low condition from which Minerva ascended to heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 19:33
verses.text: Is there truly any reason why any one should leave the worship of Him who created the earth with its living creatures, and the heaven with its stars, for the adoration of her who taught men to set up the woof? What place does he hold who taught the healing of wounds in the body? Can he be more excellent than Him who formed the body itself, and the power of sensibility and of life? Finally, did he contrive and bring to light the herbs themselves, and the other things in which the healing art consists?.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book I 20:1
verses.text: Chap.
